citation.article-title: Mycoplasma mucosicanis sp. nov., isolated from the mucosa of dogs
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Mycoplasma mucosicanis sp. nov.
Mycoplasma mucosicanis (mu.co.si.ca′nis. N.L. n. mucosa mucous membrane; L. n. canis -is a dog; N.L. gen. n. mucosicanis of mucous membranes of a dog).
Cells show moderately textured surfaces and are pleomorphic; predominantly coccoid (0.2–0.5 µm diameter), but ring-like and open ring shapes (0.2–0.5 µm in width by 0.8–1.2 µm in length) are visible.
A small proportion of the population is filterable through 220 nm-pore-size membranes.
Aerobic growth occurs at 25, 30, 37 and 42 °C but optimum temperature is 37 °C.
Colonies possess the typical fried egg appearance, film and spots production is present.
Requires serum or sterol for growth.
Acid is not produced from carbohydrates.
Arginine, aesculin and urea are not hydrolysed.
Potassium tellurite is reduced but not tetrazolium.

The polar lipid profile is mainly composed of phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol, MfEL (1-O-alkyl/alkenyl-2-O-acyl-glycero-3-phosphocholine), MfGL-II (1″-phosphocholine-2″-aminodihydroxypropane-3″-phospho-6′-α-glucopyranosyl-(1′-3)-1, 2-diacylglycerol) and an unidentified phospholipid (PL1); lysoMfEL (1-O-alkyl/alkenyl-glycero-3-phosphocholine) and several unidentified lipids are present as well.
Serologically distinguishable from other closely related species of the genus Mycoplasma.
The 16S rRNA gene and the 16S–23S rRNA intergenic spacer sequences are unique.
Isolated from canine mucosa including oral cavity and genital tract.
The type strain is 1642T ( = ATCC BAA-1895T = DSM 22457T), which was isolated from the genital mucosa of a male dog.
